keyTakeAways: Rodrigo Paz, Bolivia's first conservative president-elect in 20 years, won a decisive 54.5% of the vote in the runoff election, signaling a significant shift away from decades of leftist rule under the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party.
Paz pledged to rebuild relations with the United States, particularly with the Trump administration, and to attract foreign investment after years of U.S.-Bolivia tensions under leftist governments.
Paz rejected a proposed IMF bailout, emphasizing national sovereignty and resistance to international financial controls, a key point of distinction from previous economic policies.

The new government plans to address a severe economic crisis, including fuel shortages and hyperinflation (23% year-on-year in September 2025), by targeting fuel subsidies to poorer households via direct cash transfers.
A $3.5 billion loan and an additional $600 million in financial measures are being approved to stabilize the economy within 60 days of inauguration.

Paz emphasized 'putting the house in order' before pursuing foreign investment, including potential constitutional reforms that could affect Indigenous political representation and judicial independence.

Paz’s running mate, Edman Lara, a former police captain and social media figure, helped mobilize rural and working-class voters with populist appeals, contributing to the coalition that defeated the right-wing Jorge Quiroga.

The victory marks a break from the socialist legacy of Evo Morales, who ruled for 14 years and whose term limits prevented him from running again, and raises concerns about the future of Indigenous rights in Bolivia's political system.

Despite the shift to conservative leadership, former MAS supporters have expressed skepticism and unrest, citing past electoral frauds and political repression, leading to protests in La Paz and Santa Cruz.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, Bolivia’s first conservative president-elect in 20 years, won a decisive 54.5% of the vote in a runoff election held on October 20, 2025, ending decades of leftist rule under the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party. His victory marks a significant political shift, as he pledged to rebuild relations with the United States — particularly with the Trump administration — and to attract foreign investment, rejecting an IMF bailout that many voters viewed as a sign of foreign control. Facing a severe economic crisis, including hyperinflation (23% in September 2025), Paz announced plans to target fuel subsidies through direct cash transfers to poor families while maintaining stable prices for transport workers. His campaign, led by social media-savvy running mate Edman Lara, drew support from rural and working-class voters disillusioned with past corruption. While Paz emphasizes restoring institutional integrity and addressing judicial overreach, critics warn that reforms could threaten Indigenous representation, especially given past political shifts. The election results sparked protests in La Paz and Santa Cruz, with supporters of the former president Jorge Quiroga alleging fraud, reflecting deep skepticism about Bolivia’s electoral integrity and the legitimacy of the new conservative leadership.
title: Rodrigo Paz wins presidential runoff, becoming Bolivia’s first conservative leader in decades
